reviewText:
This is fine for what it is.  A fun little strategy game with some nice history and mechnics built in.  Nothing amazing, and not a lot of replay value after a few campaigns.  If you enjoy the period or just want something light to spend a few enjoyable hours with this is interesting.

I would be aware that it only plays in a 1200X800 window or so, which is annoying, and the graphics generally are pretty minimal.  BUt it works and seems to lack bugs, which you cannot say for tons of games.

Of the 200 games I have bought on Steam I think this is likely in the top half, and definitely in the top half in terms of fun/dollar.

reviewText:
I picked this up because it looked fun from screenshots.I wasn't wrong.Pre-Civilization Marble Age is a rather simplistic turn based historical simulation game.It took me 90 minutes to go from Athens to being the Byzantine Empire and winning the game culturally.

The game is easy to learn and in a short amount of time you'll know what you are doing.Even if it is simplistic,it has depth and you can approach the gameplay differently.You can either be a diplomat,trader or a warmonger.

Diplomacy in this game was surprinsingly good.I didn't expect much from it,but it has enough options to make it interesting.Even if I was surprised by it,I found it lacking because it is way too easy to form an alliance,and the city states/civilizations don't have relations between themselves.

Trading is simple.You choose what you want to buy/sell and select the number of ships you want to allocate to that trade.

Battles are nothing special.It isn't like in CIV games where you control your army and so on.Your job is to build soldiers/make alliances and then attack someone.A window will pop up with the estimation of the fight and you can choose to flee or engange in battle.

What is fun about this game is the random scenarios that pop up.It's a historical game that respects the history.You play as either Sparta or Athens and you are faced with various challenges like natural disasters,plagues,Persian invasion,Roman territorial expansion,Hunnic invasion,Arab territorial expansion,various barbaric tribes invading and so on.
Once a scenario like that threatens your city/empire,you are given some choices and depending on your judgement,you will exit the crisis better or worse.

Graphics are caroonish and pleasing to the eye,the UI can be adjusted and the main menu is also lacking but good enough to get the job done.

Pre-Civilization Marble Age has some weaknesses in terms of diplomacy,replayability and balance(some civs,cities are absurdly strong when it comes to army)but even in its current state,I think it is worth a shot for the ones passionate about those kind of games.

I can see this game becoming very good with some updates,tweaks in terms of balance and even some DLCs.

reviewText: If you are a fan of strategy or economic simulations then this game might be the one for you. Basically you start off in the early history of man and you can be Sparta or Athens, both of which will completely change how the game plays out. This game is as much of a puzzle as it is a strategy, each time you play you want to do better than the last time by remembering specific events that happen, quests that you have to make ready for, the order that you want to research in, and what buildings you want to build first. Don't expect to be able to choose one resource and just go for it either, you really need to constantly be adapting to the changing needs of your civilization or you will quickly find yourself falling behind. The diplomacy and trading also offer another piece of the puzzle, and they are well done in that your choices will  have a significant impact on how the game turns out for you. As a whole I would say that if you like games like Total War or Civilization then you will really be able to appreciate the subtle complexity of this exceptionally entertaining game. 10/10

Simple but fun historical game -- Plenty of different things to do, it's definitely not on rails.

reviewText:
This game is charming and simple, but has a lot to offer beneath the surface and is surprisingly challenging.

You start with just a few villagers and have to manage resources via sliders similar to Democracy, the first main goal is to keep a balanced economy capable of growth. As you play you'll research various upgrade paths that can unlock new buildings and improve your economy and army.

Occasionally you'll be presented with a challenge, often the challenges will test your military and your economy, and often failing them still allows you to play albeit with penalties.

As you play you get scouts that can explore the world, and settlers that can build extra colonies to provide bonuses to your capital. As you uncover other civilizations, you can make peace with them which allows for trade, form alliances with them which helps your army during military events, and eventually buy land from them which can increase your population capacity. Alternately, if your army is big enough and buffed enough and you have a few generals, you can conquer them.

As you expand and unify Greece and Mesopotamia, you'll get to decide whether to form an empire or kingdom, and the world map will expand, what started centered around Greece becomes centered around all of western Europe, north Africa, and the middle east, and you encounter whole other civilizations. There are a variety of choices you get to make which can impact how you win, or lose, the game.

Overall I'd say this is a great casual game, it's simple but endearing, and considering how cheap it is you could get a really good deal for your money.

reviewText:
Yes, it IS a glorified $5 flash game, but that doesn't mean its bad. This isn't the first (nor to be the last) in the series of Pre-Civilization games by a dev that knows broken English.  Its part of the enjoyment when you're informed you have too much workers.

Go online, play Pre-Civilzation: Stone Age.  Its a free flash game they made before this, and it was a flash game I loved quite a lot.  Eventually a bigger release went on steam for $5 bucks and I thought why not?  I like the game, I want to support the dev, and I want more in this series.

Its a simple resource allocator game--You have people, you make them become farmers (to increase population further), warriors (to attack other civilizations for plunder), miners (to build upgrades), as well as a few more. The game is pretty challenging on medium difficulty, and I still play every few days trying to beat medium with something better than the worst medal.  Its enjoyable, simple to get into, has a demo as well as an online flash pre-quel so that anyone can play enough of the series to know if its worth their few bucks.

reviewText:
Pros
Easy to understand the interface
Cute style

Cons
The translation from Russian is in small patches grammaticly odd, and if you press continue game after finishing the final quest a message box pops up in Russian.
Felt very linear, and completed in 3hours and that was with me wandering off and leaving the game running for over an hour.
Not sure on the replay value, you can play as Athens or Sparta and pick a starting perk, but once Greece is united I don't think it would have a huge impact.
Clicking next turn a lot without doing anything just to build resources up is quite boring.

Overall
Not bad for a steam sale 1.50 purchase, but definately wouldn't have paid full price for it. It could be better polished and needs more depth to what you are doing. Maybe a good one for younger players?

reviewText:
This is actually a surprisingly good game. It's better on your phone but the mechanics are interesting enough to justify it on Steam for short blasts.

A complete sucessfull play through will take 2-3 hours but it is well paced and the two different factions having different playstyles give it a dose of replayability.

The presentation is quite cute, there is a reasonable dash of history added in and there is surprising depth of the mechanics under the hood for something that presents as a casual game.

It is also an example of doing a sequal right, I liked this enough to track down the mobile only first game Bronze Age and you can really see how they refined the mechanics and polished the experience for this.

reviewText:
A great example of the phrase ‘the whole is more than the sum of its parts’. Marble age at its core is just a number of sliders to control different production types of an empire. But it works so well. As you develop your empire you are tasked between growing your empire and meeting certain milestones/quests that the game throws at you. The challenge comes from trying to optimise your empire in order to grow it as fast as possible – appealing to the min/max child in each of us.

Note:
Can be difficulty can be off putting to newcomers. Hard difficult is HARD.
Random events can be too powerful (really help or hinder your empires).
This is available on android. As far as portable games go (I consider most to be premium junk), this is highly recommended and if you are someone who has lots of time to kill due to travelling you should consider buying on android.

reviewText: A successful mini-game, it has enough depth and fun to make it worth both your money and time. It feels like one scenario of a large game. The simple mechanics of the game mean you will ease into it right away, but the challenge will mean you are drawn into trying to play better. Ultimately, it is thoroughly enjoyable, though I found the victory condition poorly explained. You are told you are trying to 'conquer the world' but in reality, the end-game victory is triggered by having a number of soldier, money, culture plus control/diplomacy alignment of the world. At the end of the day, it's fun! Definite recommend

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Disclaimer: The copy of this game was provided by Orlygift[www.orlygift.com]. Thank you for making this review possible!

Few words about the game
Pre-Civilization Marble Age is a quite complex but peaceful strategy game. You goal is to expand your territory, make alliances and just explore around your world. It's a really entertaining game, mostly thanks to being based on actual history, but still it's a nice way to spend free evening. It might not be the best strategy game around, especially with all those restrictions imposed by game as alot of potential development is wasted, yet it's one of the nicest I've personally played

Advantages
Lovely cartoon(ish) graphics and practical, adjustable in-game UI
Surprisingly composite technologies tree that boosts up replay value of game a bit
Lets players refresh their knowledge about Greek history (which I like even more than my own)
Price is fair enough, especially when discounts are going on
Hundreds" (In about 2.5h gameplay occured only few of those) historical events makes gameplay a bit more varied and interesting
Disadvantages
Sounds are crappy and music doesn't fit in game
Too flash-like feel of a game
Short and limited in capabilities of it
Summary
It feels a bit like this game was left out too early
date: devs could give it a little more love
recommended: it deserves it. It also might be overwhelming for newcomers but after max. 1 hour
hoursPlayed: most of players should understand mechanics completely. Anyway
voteText: it's a pleasant game
votesHelpful:
perfect to take a rest from bigger titles and just have fun expanding your little city with loads of random events on the way. Worth at least trying out!

Personal score
6.5 / 10
If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!"

reviewText:
This game has much more than what it appears to be.
I mean if you are looking for a good game to relax it's a very solid choice,
and also if you want to try to master the game and get all the achievements you are in for a world of hurt.
The game is on turns and there's some random events but overall you can make a sequence and try to find the perfect one
to get all the hard achievements.
It took me about 20 hours playing and about 100 restarts to get them all and to see pretty much everything the game has to offer but I really recommend it especially if you get it on a sale.
The Highest price I would value this game would be U$5,00 so any value you pay less for that is a very good buy.

Overall 7/10 - Just cause the sad part is there's no replay value after you try all the strats. So pretty much you will shelve it.

reviewText:
It's like a board game with more rules than a board game could ever have. Like Civilization board game (and PC game), you are constantly encouraged to specialize and then punished for your weakenesses.

I can't tell whether the random events are intelligently helping me catch up where I'm weak, but I suspect it is so, because on normal, I am only inching my way forward on highly iterative playthroughs.

I love this game for its balanced asymmetry. If you want to try the full flash game as an intro, go here: http://www.kongregate.com/games/clarusvictoria/pre-civilization-bronze-age

reviewText: I really enjoyed this game.  It is a flash game bundled into a steam app that they charge you for, but you get what you pay for.  The game plays a lot like a euro stype board game, moving workers around to collect resources while interacting with the rest of the world.  It is a lot like managing only one city in Civ.  The game does have a new game+ function that lets you carry over Civ points to make the next game easier.  First play through, I got the lowest victory and learned a bunch.  This gave me enought new game+ points to get 2 bonuses in the next game.  The second play through, I got the second best ending.  I think with the points I earned, I could pull off a top rated game in game three.  I will try here shortly.  If I do, then I can play as the second race, and I assume I will get the top score on my first try on that, then I wil be done with the game.  So, yeah, 4 play throughs and I will be done.  Was it worth the $5.  Completely.

reviewText:
(07/10) - A Decent Casual Game

Sure, this game is just a flash game, but that doesn´t mean it´s a bad game for Steam. The controls work fine so i don´t see why i should judge the game for it´s port.

The gameplay is what really caught me. You´re just sliding some sliders to assign your workers but the level of depth behind it is pretty amazing. Seeing if you can´t get that building one turn earlier or defeat the incoming enemy wave this time, there is more strategy to it than it might seem at first glance. I enjoyed boardgames with this mechanic so i had no problem to love the polished version of it in this game.
That said tho, beating the game is hard and will take multiple tries to finally do so. Luckily a decent variety of starting perks and two different factions give a nice replayability.

Onto the bad parts then. This point would usually mean i don´t recommend the game as i hate the word: random. There are some random elements that might or might not happen on which your success is based. Now as i think no game should have randomness in it, why am i still recommending it?
Becuase those things felt miner and are not what i took from the game.

If you´re looking for a casual game to spend some hours on to finally beat and then set aside, i really had fun trying to figure out what comes next and how i could improve my play...

reviewText:
A massive accomplishment in the gaming industry.
There are many things I liked about this game. Here's a few strong points: Accurate mapping, large degrees of micromanagement and lots of real events happening at the real times gave a bolder illusion of reality. It made me feel like I was a real ruler. I loved the cartooney graphics; when the models are on this scale they look really good. I enjoyed the variety of boosts and debuffs that you could have. The call the legions was great if you were Sparta (lots of generals so you can really take advantage of the 100k more units) and it was funny how on Easy you could use call the legions to get equal troops to the Romans and then overthrow them.
I couldn't find many bad things to say about this game, but they are big enough to make a point of: Real shame I couldn't play as a different city in Greece/Different country. Maybe open up a mod workshop so this is possible? The fact that I couldn't specify EXACTLY how many people I wanted doing a thing really annoyed me (Major OCD). The biggest nagging problem I found was that the Justinian Plague was REALLY confusing. For some reason sometimes things were unusable and sometimes they were and I think that because it's the least straightforward of the events it should have at least a LITTLE bit of prior instruction so you don't fail on your first time getting to that point in the game.
All in all though, great game, I'd rate 9.2/10 in it's current state, and 9.8/10 if the issues are fixed.

reviewText:
Marble Age is a fun game, particularly if you enjoyed games like Colonization, Civilization, and maybe a bit of Capitalism / tycoon-ish elements.  There is some resource management and governance things, but the interface is streamlined and idiot-proof enough that you'll figure out how it works in a jiffy.

The game runs through about 300 turns and various events based on history pop-up throughout the campaign.  The goal is to achieve victory before the last turn, and there are awards / achievements depending how early you succeed.  This may seem repetitive, but there's a lot of variance with how you build your empire, allocate resources, conduct diplomacy, and quite a bit more.  The slick interface makes all of this very easy to manage and there are helpful indicators when events need your attention.  As an added bonus for beer-and-pretzel gamers, this one is 100% mouse-controllable.  :)

If you enjoy strategy games and maybe tycoon games, this one is an easy buy--heck, it's worth a lot more in terms of dollars per hour for me already.

reviewText: This game looks and feels like a Flash game.  There is a definite beginning and end to the game, but it doesn't feel like a complete, compelling experience.  You can choose between two different civilizations to play as, but there is no real variety; it's the same thing each and every time.  Normally, there is a degree of randomness and variety in strategy games that doesn't seem to be present here.  While there are extra screens for managing things like diplomacy and science, turns play out on a screen that represents what your civilization is doing.  You have a certain population, and you use sliders to increase or decrease the number of people assigned to particular tasks.  Each task generates one more resources for your civilization, and new tasks are unlocked by building new buildings".\n\nSo
date: aside from dipping briefly into other screens when needed
recommended: all you do is adjust resource production on the main screen with slide controls
hoursPlayed: and click end turn.  I'm not at all opposed to games that use a minimal style--my favorite strategy game is MO1.  But something about it just doesn't work here and I can't recommend it at all.\n\nBut
voteText: as with all games that have demos
helpfulPercent: I recommend you try it for yourself and see if you like it.  I ended up buying it because it was heavily discounted and I wanted to see if the game improved.  I don't hate it
votesHelpful: but I don't particularly like it either."

reviewText: This game is an on-rails glorified Flash game that's simply not worth playing more than once.  Its roots are in Flash and mobile games and it shows. reviewText:
(English Review, Translated russian review below) This is well develpoped, and accessible for many.

It is not bad for a four dollar game, it is very well develeoped and quite alot of effort was put into this game, assuming a two person team made this. It has a website, video gameplay example, good user interface, fun graphic animation, relaxing music, and good sound effects.

Also, because of the cheap price, very fast download speed, and simple graphics, it makes it playable for many people.

However,
It is not that replayable because it only has two civilizations you can play, and after beating the game you cannot continue, but since it just got released, they have enough time to add more. Also, it did inherit some ideas of other games, and is not a new thing. But overall, this game is quite good and the develper(s) have potential to create more, easily assessible, and well develop games in the future. I look forward to it.

---
Это хорошо develpoped и доступными для многих.

Это не плохо для игры в четыре доллара, это очень хорошо develeoped и довольно много усилий было вложено в эту игру , предполагая, чтодва человек команды сделал это . Он имеет веб-сайт, пример видео геймплей, хороший пользовательский интерфейс , весело графической анимацией , расслабляющая музыка , и хорошие звуковые эффекты.

Кроме того, из-за дешевой цене , очень быстрая скорость загрузки, и простой графикой , это делает его воспроизводиться для многих людей.

Тем не менее ,
Это не то, что replayable , потому что он имеет только две цивилизации можно играть , и после прохождения игры вы не можете продолжать , но, поскольку он только что получил освобожден, что они имеют достаточно времени, чтобы добавить больше. Кроме того, он сделал наследуют некоторые идеи других игр , и неновая вещь . Но в целом , эта игра является достаточно хорошим иdevelper ( ы ) имеют потенциал для создания более легко assessible , и хорошо разрабатывать игры в будущем. Я с нетерпением жду этого.

voteText: then the entire third row.\n\nThere's no ability to really spec into any particular strength or weakness. If you wanted to make a colony with no army and become a massive trading civilization
helpfulPercent: you're ♥♥♥♥ out of luck because you're basically forced to make a half-♥♥♥♥♥ army since your talent tree in both culture and production incentivize doing so.\n\nIdunno. I had really high hopes because I played the other two free games several times through
votesHelpful: and the overall steam rating was high. But this game doesn't deserve it's "Very Positive" rating in my opinion."
